bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to Richard Perry, July 13, 1720

div1.p: Robert Carter writes at length to London merchant Richard Perry (son of Micajah), July 13, 1720, thanking him for his advice about handling attacks of gout; Carter will no longer drink claret. He finds the prices realized for his tobacco quite acceptable but warns again of his concern about selling his tobacco near the end of the market, and then comments on Perry's complaint of Carter's tobacco having "a Smoaky smell," noting that it is necessary to use fires in the curing houses when there is "funky foggy weather." He agrees with Perry that the opening of the "The Spanish Trade as well as the French" should make good markets for tobacco, and notes that ship captains will be reporting at home the Virginian's expectations of the best crop in some years. He is resolving to be more careful in his tobacco production since he is irritated that Mr. Pratt gets better prices for tobacco "that comes from all parts of their County low lands as well as high" when his own lands are better. He continues with comments on his bank stock and annuities, and "printed proposals of the South Sea Company & the Bank to the Parliament" which Col. Harrison had when Carter was in Williamsburg. He asks that Perry "act wth. the same prudent regard to my Interest as you Do for Yor. own." And he adds some remarks about his upcoming heavy expenses. He concludes by thanking Perry for "the commendable Character You give me of my Son" which pleases Carter as the expenses of John's education have been heavy and any more would have left him "at a loss to know how to keep the rest of my family from want."

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to Richard Perry, July 13, 1720

opener.dateline:
Rappahannock, [Lancaster County, Virginia]
July 13 1720
Mr. Richd. Perry

div1.p:
Yors. of the 13th. of Feb. By a Marylander
came to me 5 Days agon, The kind advice You give me for
the managemt of my self in the Gout is very Acceptable, I
have had no touch of It since my first fitt. It made me quite
leave off Drinking Clarrett as I resolve to do every thing else
I shall be advis'd
That may any ways contribute to that Distemper—

The prizes You have sold my Tobacco at hitherto I am well Enough
pleasd wth. If you do but put off the rest as well I shall be easy.
These lagg Sales are always a terrour to me You complain of some
of my Tobo. having a Smoaky smell I do not know the meaning
of It, our Tobo. houses are Separated farr enough from our
Q[uarte] rs indeed Sometimes in funky foggy weather when Tobo. is just upon turning we are forst
to make smothers under our howses in our howses to Dry It, & this is what's
practiced by the best planters in virginia & Ever was since I
have bin acquainted wth. The making of Tobo., We have
hopes The Spanish Trade as well as the French being open
You will not find Yor. selves mistaking in Yor. Expectati[on]
of a Standing Markett for some Years, we reckon we have had
a great many fewer Ships This Year than the last, indeed
they'l all go neer to return full & Some Tobacco will be left
& They will bring You the Storey of a fair Crop being in
the Ground. but how that will Issue no body knows It
looks hitherto to promise to be better Tobo. than we have
had for some Years I take up resoluts: to be nicer in the
handling of mine than Ever I was Yett, It troubles
me not a little that Mr. Pratt should gett more for
his Miscelaneous stuff that comes from all parts of
their County low lands as well as high than I do
for mine that is made wth. my own people & upon as good &
proper [lands] as any body can boast of

You have sett me right about my bank Stock I was afraid 100 taken away would have
prov'd 100 Diminution but It seems the remaining 90 Stands in the place of
The 100, Yor. observation of the Annuities I can say little to more Than I
already have. In the begining of May at Wmsburg Colo. Harrison by some
means had gott the printed proposals of the South Sea Company & the Bank
to the Parliament, wch. presently alarm'd me and from York Rivr.
I writ to You abt . It. Desiring You would act wth. the same prudent
regard to my Interest as you Do for Yor. own there I left
It then And So I think must do now. That annuity what time
I had come in It whether 96 or 99 Years I never Yett knew. You may
please to remember that fund was never yett very grateful
to me I took It in compliment to You because You told me you had
purchasd It for me otherwise I had rather bin wth.out It 4 perCt. is
so poor a premio I will never take so little again This Year
I Shall find so many ways for the Drawing out my money I have
no occasion to try contrive new ones for letting go any more upon Interest. [ . . . ] the bank stock & the
Annuity I have already [ . . . ] If you do not find It necessary to
take in my money I would have [ . . . ] Yor. Father in his Lettr. of the 20th of Feb. tells
me the bank Doth buy up all the Annuities they can
whether this will be any Salve to me I know not Tis
all in a great Measure a mysterie to us & So I Shall pass It,
The part I am to hold in Bagwells Ship, a Draft of £500
I made on You t'other Day to Collo. Jenings & some other large
uses I must make of you in a Short time will sink me low
enough If not too low I'm afraid for any present thots. of further
purchases

You please me very well in the commendable Character You
give me of my Son. 'tis no small Sattisfaction to me to have
a pennyworth for my Penny to have spent so much money upon
a dunce or a Blockhead had bin most Intollerable & Yett
After all to have a finicall inside & not a Suitable Cover-
=ing for the out Side will make but a Schymity gentleman I'm
Suspicious Mr. Randolph hath bad & mean company to be sure
hath bin the bane of many a Young man but certainly £200
per Annum is no such Scanty Allowance to lay him under any
Such Disadvantage If It be, I shall be at a loss to know
how to keep the rest of my family from want That Yors. may
Swim in a much Greater Affluence is the Cordial Desire of
div1.closer:
Sir Yor. sincere humble Servt.
In my Acct. Currt. you omitted
giving me credit for my 30
hogsheads of Tobo. per Hancock indeed You
likewise omit making me debtor
with a large bill you have pd. for me
both which I expect will have their birth
in my next Accot.

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Robert Carter Letter Book, 1720 July-1721 July, BR 227, Huntington Library, Art Collections, and Botanical Gardens, San Marino, California. Printed: Wright. Letters of Robert Carter. . . . pp. 1-4.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The county and colony have been added for clarity.

[1] Louis Wright has speculated that Mr. Pratt might be William Pratt of Gloucester County as there were several Pratts active in Virginia at this time. In his letter to Micajah and Richard Perry written this same day, RC noted that "Mr. Pratt took care of those [letters] for James rivr & York" which makes Wright's speculation as good as any. In the close-knit society of his time and class, RC would certainly have learned what others were receiving for their crops, but a definite identification of the irritating Mr. Pratt is not possible. (Wright. Letters of Robert Carter. . . . p. 2.)
